concepts.interpretation: Conditions precedent to retrenchment requiring notice, compensation at time of retrenchment, and notice to government. Court holds inapplicable due to closure under S.25FFF.

anchor.surface_text: 25FFF. Compensation to workmen in case of closing down of undertakings Where an undertaking is closed down for any reason whatsoever,

concepts.interpretation: Applies to closure of undertaking including specific project like construction work. For construction undertakings completed after 2 years, entitled to notice and compensation as per S.25F. 'Undertaking' means specific project, not entire business.

issues.text: The short question thus requiring determination is whether S. 25F(b) or s. 25FFF(2) of the Act is attracted to the facts of this case.

anchor.surface_text: The short question thus requiring determination is whether S. 25F b or s. 25FFF 2 of the Act is attracted to the facts of this case. In order to appreciate the true scheme and scope of these sections it would be helpful to reproduce them 25F. Conditions precedent to retrenchment of workmen No workman in any industry who has been in companytinuous service for number less than one year.

issues.text: Whether the notice of retrenchment was in accordance with the provisions of s. 25F of the Act because the retrenchment compensation was to be paid immediately at the time of effecting the retrenchment and it could not be deferred.

anchor.surface_text: The last point urged on behalf of Shri Naidu was that the numberice of retrenchment was number in accordance with the provisions of s. 25F of the Act because the retrenchment companypensation was to be paid immediately at the time of effecting the retrenchment and it companyld number be deferred. According to the numberice Shri Naidu was merely informed that he companyld receive the retrenchment companypensation from the cashier within two days from the date of termination of his employment

issues.text: Whether the plea of statutory defect in the notice was sufficiently specific and precise.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the statutory defect in the numberice should, in our opinion, have been reasonably specific and precise so as to enable the appellant to meet it. The general plea companyld number serve the object of putting the appellant on guard about the precise case to be met at the trial and tell the management the precise nature of the plea with respect to the defect in the numberice, lo enable them to meet it.

issues.text: Whether the Ranchi Housing Project constitutes closure of an undertaking under s. 25FFF.

anchor.surface_text: The word undertaking as used in S. 25FFF seems to us to have been used in its ordinary sense companynoting thereby any work, enterprise, project or business undertaking. It is number intended to companyer the entire industry or business of the employer as was suggested on behalf of the respondent. Even closure or stoppage of a part of the business or activities of the employer would seem in law to be companyered by this sub-section.

issues.text: Whether there was any unfair labour practice or victimisation or mala fides in the retrenchment.

Ltd., Shri Naidu had been serving as a companystruction foreman in the Damodar Valley Corporation Ltd., during the period 1950 to 1957 and that on February 18, 1960 he applied to the Hindustan Steel Ltd., for a technical post mentioning his qualifications for the post applied for.

arguments.claim: Retrenchment of Shri Naidu was proper, justified, legal, fair and bona fide as the Ranchi Housing Project was wound up after completion.

arguments.claim: Closure of project amounts to closure under S.25FFF even if not entire business; analogous to precedents.
Under S.25FFF(1), statutory fiction treats closure as retrenchment under S.25F; notice complied.
Management has discretion to organise business; retrenchment due to reorganisation not unfair.

holdings.text: The retrenchment of Shri Naidu was proper and justified.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ranchi Housing Project closed under S.25FFF; notice complied via statutory fiction; defect plea not specifically raised; no mala fides.

holdings.text: S. 25FFF applies, not S. 25F(b), as Ranchi Housing Project is closure of undertaking.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Undertaking closed down; S.25FFF(1) incorporates S.25F notice/compensation; sub-s(2) excludes full compensation for construction completed within 2 years but project exceeded.

holdings.text: Ranchi Housing Project constitutes 'undertaking' under S.25FFF; closure of specific project/part of business covered.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning; distinct venture with beginning/end; Tribunal finding upheld; precedents like Indian Leaf Tobacco (partial closure).

holdings.text: Retrenchment notice complies with S.25F requirements as incorporated by S.25FFF(1).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory fiction treats closure as retrenchment; Ex.7 clearly complies; no failure admitted if S.25F(b) inapplicable.

holdings.text: Plea of statutory defect in notice must be specific and precise; general pleas insufficient.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness requires specificity to avoid surprise and allow response; paras 13/15 too general.

holdings.text: No unfair labour practice, victimisation or mala fides in retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of mala fides on the part of the management in retrenching Shri Naidu was also repelled by the Tribunal... failed to substantiate that there was any unfair labour practice or victimisation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal repelled unsubstantiated pleas; no cogent ground to interfere under Art.136.

holdings.text: Last come first go principle inapplicable to temporary appointment terminable without notice.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Naidus appointment being temporary terminable by the Company at any time without assigning any reason and without giving any notice was held to be an agreement contrary to the said principle and the provisions of S. 25B...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contractual terms allow termination without notice; S.25B inapplicable per Tribunal, upheld.

holdings.text: Managerial discretion allows reorganisation leading to retrenchment without unfair practice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents like Parry support bona fide reorganisation causing surplusage.

precedents.citation: Hari Prasad Shiv Shankar Shukla v. A. D. Divekar

anchor.surface_text: In Hari Prasad Shiv Shankar Shukla v. A. D. Divekar 1  it was held that this section was number intended by the Legislature to be applicable to bona fide closure of business. This decision led to amendment of the Act by the Parliament.

precedents.cited_proposition: this section was number intended by the Legislature to be applicable to bona fide closure of business

precedents.citation: Parry Co. Ltd. v. P. C. Lal

anchor.surface_text: In Parry Co. Ltd. v. P. C. Lal 2  it was observed that it was within the managerial discretion of an employer to organise and arrange his business in the manner he companysidered best and that if a bona fide scheme for such re-organisation results in surplusage of employees, numberemployer is expected to carry on the burden of such economic deadweight and retrenchment has to be accepted as inevitable, however unfortunate.
